questions.question: After using the simulator, what did you observe about the register alias table when multiple instructions write to the same register?

answers.a: The system generates an error message
answers.c: Each instruction gets assigned a different reservation station tag

explanations.a: Incorrect. The Tomasulo algorithm handles this situation transparently.
explanations.b: Incorrect. All instructions can proceed thanks to register renaming.
explanations.c: Correct. Register renaming assigns different reservation station tags to eliminate false dependencies (WAW hazards).
explanations.d: Incorrect. Register renaming prevents stalling in this situation.

questions.question: Based on your simulation experience, what happens when an instruction's operands become available?

answers.b: The instruction becomes ready and can begin execution when a functional unit is free
answers.c: The instruction is removed from the reservation station
answers.d: The instruction broadcasts its result on the CDB

explanations.a: Incorrect. The instruction still needs time to execute.
explanations.b: Correct. When operands are ready, the instruction becomes eligible for execution but must wait for an available functional unit.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The instruction stays in the reservation station until completion.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Broadcasting happens after execution completes.

questions.question: In the simulation, what visual indicator shows that an instruction is waiting for operands?

answers.a: The instruction appears in red color
answers.b: Reservation station tags appear in the Qj/Qk fields instead of values

explanations.a: Incorrect. Color coding is not the primary indicator.
explanations.b: Correct. When operands are not ready, the reservation station shows tags (like 'Add1', 'Mul2') in the Qj/Qk fields instead of actual values.
explanations.c: Incorrect. There is no 'BLOCKED' status display.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Functional units don't use blinking indicators.

questions.question: From your simulation experience, what did you observe about instruction completion order?

answers.a: Instructions always complete in program order
answers.b: Instructions complete in reverse program order
answers.c: Instructions complete out-of-order based on operand availability and execution time

explanations.a: Incorrect. This would be in-order execution, not the Tomasulo algorithm.
explanations.b: Incorrect. There's no systematic reverse ordering.
explanations.c: Correct. Instructions complete as soon as their execution finishes, which depends on operand availability and execution latency, resulting in out-of-order completion.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The completion order follows logical rules based on dependencies and timing.

questions.question: What performance metric did you notice improved most with the Tomasulo algorithm?

answers.c: Overall instruction throughput (IPC - Instructions Per Cycle)

explanations.a: Incorrect. Individual instruction latencies remain the same.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Memory latency is not directly affected by instruction scheduling.
explanations.c: Correct. The Tomasulo algorithm improves instruction throughput by enabling parallel execution of independent instructions, increasing IPC.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Cache performance is independent of instruction scheduling.

questions.question: During simulation, when did you observe the Common Data Bus (CDB) being most active?

answers.a: When instructions are being issued to reservation stations
answers.b: When multiple instructions complete execution simultaneously
answers.d: When instructions are waiting for operands

explanations.a: Incorrect. Issuing instructions doesn't cause CDB activity.
explanations.b: Correct. The CDB broadcasts results when instructions complete execution, so it's most active when multiple instructions finish around the same time.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Idle processors generate no CDB activity.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Waiting for operands doesn't generate CDB broadcasts.

questions.question: What did you observe about reservation station utilization during long dependency chains?

answers.b: Only one type of reservation station is used
answers.c: Reservation stations fill up with waiting instructions

explanations.a: Incorrect. Long dependency chains cause instructions to queue up.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Different instruction types use different reservation station types.
explanations.c: Correct. When instructions depend on previous results, they accumulate in reservation stations waiting for their operands, leading to higher utilization.
explanations.d: Incorrect. All instructions must go through reservation stations in the Tomasulo algorithm.

questions.question: After experimenting with the simulator, which factor most significantly limits instruction-level parallelism?

answers.b: True data dependencies (RAW hazards) between instructions
answers.c: Speed of the Common Data Bus
answers.d: Complexity of the register renaming hardware

explanations.a: Incorrect. While limited stations cause structural hazards, they're not the primary ILP limitation.
explanations.b: Correct. True data dependencies create unavoidable sequential constraints that fundamentally limit how many instructions can execute in parallel.
explanations.c: Incorrect. CDB speed is typically not the primary bottleneck.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Register renaming enables parallelism rather than limiting it.

questions.question: Based on your simulation analysis, what would be the most effective way to improve performance in a workload with frequent structural hazards?

answers.a: Increase the number of reservation stations

explanations.a: Correct. Structural hazards occur when hardware resources (like reservation stations) are insufficient. Adding more reservation stations directly addresses this bottleneck.
explanations.b: Incorrect. While helpful for overall performance, this doesn't address structural hazards specifically.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Branch prediction doesn't solve resource availability issues.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Memory bandwidth doesn't affect reservation station availability.
